subject: Re: Digest Number 899
msgSnippet: Rainsberger, ... How do I do that? I don t think i have VAJ un system CLASSPATH. How do I know for sure?? Also, how do I add VAJ s binaries to the system PATH
messageBody:
Rainsberger,

> 1. Remove VAJ from your system CLASSPATH *or*
> 2. Add VAJ's binaries to your system PATH

How do I do that?

I don't think i have VAJ un system CLASSPATH. How do I know for sure??
Also, how do I add VAJ's binaries to the system PATH - I think this
might be a better solution..

Thanks in advnce.

Lily.

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@r...>
wrote:
> >So said ok_lilya on 2003-06-19 --------------------
> >Allan,
> >
> >I tried this already too. The problem is not in JUnit being
exported
> >from VAJ. The problem is in the method call to inVAJava() from
JUnit.
> >That method only returns true if it can execute
> >Class.forName("com.ibm.uvm.tools.DebugSupport");
> >The only time it can execute the above line, is when there are
native
> >IBM Java classes available, specificaly uvmtools in
java.library.path.
> >I have exported all the native classes into a jar file and run the
> >program with the native jars in the classpath. It cannot find the
> >linking class to DebugSupport.
>
> Here is the problem, as far as I can tell.
>
> * The Java class is in the class path
> * The NATIVE library is not in the System PATH
>
> Therefore
>
> * JUnit *thinks* that it's running in VAJ, but
> * The native library that JUnit/VAJ needs is not available outside
VAJ
>
> SOLUTIONS
>
> 1. Remove VAJ from your system CLASSPATH *or*
> 2. Add VAJ's binaries to your system PATH
>
> Try that.
>
>
> J. B. Rainsberger,
